Work-friendly cafes in Singapore you can really get work done in

Coffee + WiFi + Power outlets

I’m a visual designer working remotely in Singapore, which means I spend most days in the comfort of my home. Sometimes, though, when I need a change in environment, I’d go to a cafe to get my work done.

The problem is that it’s incredibly difficult to find cafes to work in. By “work”, I mean actual, serious work—creating mockups on Sketch, liaising with colleagues via Slack, having video calls on Skype.

This means the ideal work-friendly cafe has to have:

  1. reliable WiFi,
  2. power outlets (this is really important and hard to find),
  3. a friendly environment that allows you to stay for long periods of time, and
  4. good coffee

A google of “work-friendly cafes in Singapore” will give you plenty of results, but most articles you’ll find are influencer-type listicles, in which the definition of “work” seems to be typing on your laptop (or iPad!) for 30 minutes.

That’s not going to cut it.

So here’s my own list of 12 cafes that I’ve been to and have fulfilled the four criteria outlined above.

But first, a few tips:

Cafe etiquette

The most important thing about working in cafes is to not be an ass! And it’s really simple:

  • Be nice to the staff (smile and say “Thanks” when they serve you your coffee)
  • Order some food to go with your drink if you’re staying for more than 1 hour (you could stagger your orders and get a cuppa first, followed by some food when you get hungry)
  • When it’s peak period and tables are getting filled, consider leaving if you’ve been at your seat for a few hours
  • Some cafes ask their patrons to share tables; if you’re not comfortable with that, don’t go to cafes with shared tables or seats

Google Maps is your friend

When planning your remote working cafe trip, always consult Google Maps. You’ll not only be able to judge the quality of the coffee by the reviews, but also be able to predict if the cafe is going to be busy by using a nifty feature called “Popular times”:

Data collection: creepy but useful

Sometimes Google won’t show the popular times of a cafe because it hasn’t collected enough data from its users yet. This might mean, however, that the cafe is sufficiently unknown and thus likely to be relatively empty.
